revision.text:
'''Equity Schools''' is a Chicago-based firm focused on solving capital and operational funding problems for schools, businesses, and other organizations. They primarily work with public, private, charter, and independent schools, and are known for using various non-conventional funding methods, or “nonlinear project funding.”
The firm was founded in 2001 by its current president [[Richard R. Murray]], who is most known for his invention of the corporate work study program used by the [[Cristo Rey Network]].
== History == Murray's creation and first use of the nonlinear model was in 1996 when he was approached by [[Cristo Rey Jesuit High School (Chicago)|Cristo Rey High School in Chicago]] to help them find a way to fund their new school. The group had few assets and no plan of how they would create a quality program that would be affordable to inner city students.<ref>{{Cite book|title=More than a dream: the Cristo Rey story: how one school's vision is changing the world.|last=Kearney|first=G.R.|publisher=Loyola Press|year=2008|isbn=978-0-8294-2576-5|location=Chicago, Illinois|pages=76–77}}</ref>
The program Murray designed is based upon the concepts of [[job sharing]] and [[Professional employer organization|employee leasing]]; Cristo Rey students attend class four days per week, and then attend a corporate internship at a Chicago business on the fifth day. The revenues generated by these internships cover a great majority of tuition costs for Cristo Rey students, which helps keep their tuition rates low.
After implementation of this plan the Chicago community school saw its dropout rate decline from 75% to 1%, with 100% of graduates being accepted to college.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/in-a-class-by-itself/|title=In A Class By Itself|access-date=2017-04-10|language=en}}</ref> The Cristo Rey Network now successfully operates this program at 32 schools across 21 states.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cristoreynetwork.org/about|title=About - Cristo Rey Network|website=www.cristoreynetwork.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-04-10}}</ref>
Murray's experience creating the nonlinear method when working with Cristo Rey led him to found Equity Schools in 2001.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Encyclopedia of educational reform and dissent.|last=Hunt|first=T. C.|publisher=SAGE Publications|year=2010|isbn=1412956641|location=|pages=236}}</ref> Since its creation Equity Schools has worked with seven schools in the US to plan and implement solutions to funding problems. Projects that have implemented nonlinear models created by Equity Schools have seen a 100% success rate.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://equityschools.org/portfolio/|title=Portfolio - Equity Schools - Nonlinear Project Funding|work=Equity Schools - Nonlinear Project Funding|access-date=2017-04-10|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Nonlinear Project Funding == The nonlinear approach used by Equity Schools is a method at working through funding problems when conventional sources of funding are not enough to accomplish a project or maintain operations. Conventional, or “linear,” sources of funding often rely upon fundraising and government programs (loans, grants, tax referendums). By contrast, a nonlinear approach may use conventional funding sources where applicable, but then examines relationships and existing revenue streams to identify sufficient funding from several, often non-obvious sources.<ref>Murray, R. R. (2017, April 8). [Telephone interview].</ref>
Utilizing multiple diverse sources for funding makes a nonlinear approach highly conducive to a customized, self-sustaining funding strategy to support projects and operations. This approach is comprehensive as it includes factors such as a school's curriculum, character and culture, finances, real estate, and long-term educational, operational, and capital needs.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.a4le.org/websites/regions_and_chapters/index.php?p=592|title=Association for Learning Environments|website=www.a4le.org|language=en|access-date=2017-04-10}}</ref>
== References == <references />
== External links == * [http://equityschools.org/ Official website]
[[Category:Education finance]] [[Category:Financial services companies of the United States]]

{{distinguish|foundation degree|Foundation Year Programme}} {{Refimprove|date=August 2013}} A '''foundation course''' is a preparatory course for university-level art and design education, used particularly in the [[United Kingdom]].
==Description== The foundation course is a one or two year preparatory course for school-leavers who want to qualify for a place on a [[bachelor's degree]] course in art, design or architecture. The course is almost entirely practical in nature, although increasingly elements of art and design history have been introduced, and it is considered sufficient to qualify those who pass it to move on to a degree course without further study. It is the dominant form of entry to university and art college degree courses in the United Kingdom, but versions of it exist in several other countries, particularly where British influence over art education has been historically strong. In [[Ireland]] it is known as the Core Studies course, and versions of the foundation course also exist in [[Australia]], [[Canada]], [[Cyprus]], [[Malta]], [[Malaysia]] and [[New Zealand]].
==Origin and methodology== [[Harry Thubron]] at [[Leeds College of Art]]. Together they began to establish a team to deliver a new form of art preparation course they called the Basic Design Course. The aim of the course was to teach what were considered to be the basic skills that underpin all art and design activities, including architecture. This resulted in projects designed to develop skills in using colour, articulating two- and three-dimensional space, defining form and experimenting with diverse materials. Many of these theories were tested by Thubron at a series of art summer schools in the seaside town of [[Scarborough, North Yorkshire]], which attracted art students, artists and art teachers from throughout Britain. The result of this was that the theories of the basic design course were very widely disseminated, which helped the programme to become so widespread.
This approach to preparing art and design students for degree level study had its origins in the writings of [[Herbert Read]], and Coldstream, Thubron and Read regularly met to discuss their ideas at Read's house in the village of [[Stonegrave]], North Yorkshire. Read's ideas had their origin the German [[Bauhaus]] school of art, which had used a similar method prior to its closure by the [[Nazis]] in 1933.
A notable feature of this method of the foundation course method is that it does not teach basic versions of later art or design practices, so that someone wanting to be a painter would not be taught basic painting, or a student wanting to be a graphic designer would not be taught basic graphic design. Specific skills were left to be taught in the specific degree course itself, whereas the foundation course only focused on the core skills that are perceived to be common to all art and design practices.
==Current status==
* University of the Arts London Awarding Body<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.arts.ac.uk/about-ual/awarding-body/|title=About UAL|last=|first=|last2=|date=|website=|publisher=University of Arts London|language=en-uk|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-03-29}}</ref> * [[Edexcel]] * [[Welsh Joint Education Committee]] * ABC Awards<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abcawards.co.uk/ |title=ABC Awards |publisher=ABC Awards |date= |accessdate=2017-02-27}}</ref> * [[Ascentis]]
Outside of the UK most Foundation Course programmes are validated by universities or national education authorities, although the programmes in Malta and Cyprus are validated by UK examining boards.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.ucas.ac.uk/students/choosingcourses/specificsubjects/artanddesign/foundationcourses/ UCAS Foundation Course information]
[[Category:Education terminology]] [[Category:Educational qualifications in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:School examinations]] [[Category:School qualifications]]

'''François Thibaut''' (born January 3, 1948) is an educator known for developing the ''Thibaut Technique'' [[second language acquisition]] method for children and is the Founder/Director of ''The Language Workshop for Children'' (“LWFC”)He currently operates nationwide educational centers based in New York City.<ref name="talklikeny">{{cite web| title = To Talk Like New York, Sign Up for Spanish| author = Qjito, Mirta | publisher = [[The New York Times]]| date = 1999-10-18|url = https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9801E1DA1739F93BA25753C1A96F958260&sec=&spon=&&scp=4&sq=francois%20thibaut&st=cse}}</ref> Thibaut’s technique is the basis of the curriculum offered at LWFC programs and in the [[Professor Toto]] children’s language education animation. The LWFC begins teaching languages to children at the age of six months, when they’re preverbal.<ref name="blngualbaby"/>[[Image:Thibaut.jpg|frame|right|Francois Thibaut at the Language Workshop For Children]]
==Childhood Observations, The Basis of the Thibaut Technique== At the age of six Thibaut was enrolled at the [[Collège Sainte-Barbe|College Saint Barbe boarding school in Paris]] where teachers intentionally made little to no effort to translate or explain the meaning of the French language curriculum in which newly arriving, non-French speaking students found themselves immersed. Instead, after six weeks of absorbing French in a context-rich language immersion classroom, the non-French elementary age children would begin speaking French in single words. Then by week eight they were speaking in two, and then three word sentences. Eventually, by 2½ months they were constructing complete, accent-free French sentences, correctly attributing noun genders, and using past, present, and future tenses. Years later Thibaut realized that he’d observed a strong example of what neurolinguist [[Eric Lenneberg]] later identified in his book Biological Foundations of Language (1967) what he termed the [[critical period]] in language development. Thibaut’s childhood observations eventually led him to bring immersive, emotionally stimulating, context-rich, language classes founding his Cercle Franco Americain (later Language Workshop for Children) classes in New York, NY in the early 1970s. Thus, the Thibaut Technique was introduced into American culture.<ref name="blngualbaby">{{cite web| title = Bilingual Babies, A Sign of the Times| author = Sreenivasan, Hari | publisher = [[Nightline (US news program)|ABC Nightline]]| date = 2007-01-30|url = https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9801E1DA1739F93BA25753C1A96F958260&sec=&spon=&&scp=4&sq=francois%20thibaut&st=cse}}</ref><ref name="superbaby">{{cite web| title = The Super Baby Burnout Syndrome| author = Elder, Janet | publisher = [[The New York Times]]| date = 1980-01-08|url = https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=940DE4D71539F93BA35752C0A96F948260&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=3}}</ref>
This approach has often been attributed to baby language enrichment products first introduced for VCR’s in the mid-1990s. While many of these brands have had more national exposure, Thibaut’s technique was in existence for more than 20 years prior to their debut.
==Early Teaching Experience== Thibaut emigrated to [[New York City]] in 1973, when foreign language instruction was strongly focused on high school and college students. As a teacher he was frustrated by watching his college-age students continually struggle the same drill and translation-based French so he began focusing on younger learners, abandoned translation-drills, and adopted the context-rich, language acquisition devices that he observed at his own elementary school in the 1950s, adding his own brand of playfulness, color, and humor.
==The Language Workshop for Children== Since 1973, his internationally recognized Language Workshop for Children has offered stimulating language lessons for babies, toddlers and elementary grades. Original music, vocabulary-building songs, language immersion, festive visual aids, action games and native-fluent language teachers are why the LWFC is the country’s leader in children’s language educational play. As Thibaut says, “Children remember the words that make them happy”.
==The French Language Salon== In 2011, Thibaut drew on his successful technique with children by offering friendly, situationally relevant classes through his French Language Salon® classes for adults. Thibaut’s new adult method immediately integrates grammar and conversation, rather than teaching them as separate disciplines. Thibaut’s former child students often attend his adult classes to practice French for social and professional purposes. Thibaut also designed a test preparation program for students of varying levels who are working to pass in exams focused on French as a second language and comply with the [[Common European Framework of Reference for Languages]].
Thibaut specializes in different types of test preparation that merge his original French teaching style with patterns that correlating to the pertaining exam (SAT, AP French, CEFRL, and Canadian TEF.) He combines his French education experience with an understanding of the exams and their tendencies, inspired by the, “life-hack,” movement and applied to a more academic and professional sphere.
==Technology== With the growth of technology at the turn of the new century, Thibaut expanded his outreach platforms beyond the classroom by producing his [[Professor Toto]] Language Education Series for children, available in original CD/DVD and downloadable formats through Amazon, as well as making his language lessons and test prep services available via Skype.
==Notes== {{reflist}}
;Further reading *Shea, Sarah B. (2004–12). [http://www.languageworkshopforchildren.com/docs/Parents.pdf "The Best Baby Classes"]. Parents Magazine. *Langley, Monica. (1999-10-06). [http://www.languageworkshopforchildren.com/docs/WallStreetJournal.pdf "Bringing Up (Bilingual) Baby"]. The Wall Street Journal. *Millard, Pauline M. (2001-06-24). [http://www.languageworkshopforchildren.com/docs/AssociatedPress.pdf "No-so-foreign words"]. Associated Press. *Hirsch, Joy. (1998-07-30). [http://www.languageworkshopforchildren.com/docs/BBCNews.pdf "Early learning is thriving in New York"]. BBC USA Direct News. *Holman, Jennifer R. (1998-01). [http://www.languageworkshopforchildren.com/docs/BetterHomes.pdf "Learning a Language"]. Better Homes and Gardens. *McKeon, Nancy & Pollan, Corky. (1984-11-5). [http://www.languageworkshopforchildren.com/docs/NewYorkMagazine.pdf "Small Talk"]. New York Magazine. *Thibaut, Francois. (1999-05-31). [http://www.professortoto.com/docs/People_053199.pdf "Small Talk"]. People Magazine. *Gangwer, Kristin. (2007-04-03). [https://archive.is/20080706005006/http://www.babble.com/content/articles/columns/infantindustry/007/index.aspx "Infant Industry: Mandarin for Babies? How to make your child multi-lingual"]. Babble.com.
==External links== *[http://www.LanguageWorkshopForChildren.com The Language Workshop for Children] ([http://www.LanguageWorkshopForChildren.com www.LanguageWorkshopForChildren.com]) children's educational program *[http://www.frenchlanguagesalon.com French Language Salon] ([http://www.FrenchLanguageSalon.com www.FrenchLanguageSalon.com]) adult conversation courses *[http://www.ProfessorToto.com Professor Toto] ([http://www.ProfessorToto.com www.ProfessorToto.com]) language education series
{{Authority control}}

{{Infobox University |name =Ghent University |native_name =Universiteit Gent |latin_name =Academia Gandavensis |image_name =Braemtzegel.png | caption = Seal of Ghent University |motto ="Inter Utrumque" |mottoeng ="In Between Both" |established =1817 |affiliations =[[Conference of European Schools for Advanced Engineering Education and Research|CESAER]]
[[Erasmus Student Network]]
[[European University Association]]
[[Santander Network]] |type =[[Public university|Public]] |city ={{flagicon|Belgium}} [[Ghent]] |country =[[Belgium]] |students =+41,000 |staff =9,000 |rector =[[Rik Van de Walle]] |former_names =State University of Ghent |website ={{URL|http://www.ugent.be}} |logo =Ghent University logo.svg |logo_size = 150px |campus=University town}} '''Ghent University''' ({{lang-nl|Universiteit Gent}}, abbreviated as '''UGent''') is a [[Public university|public]] research [[university]] located in [[Ghent]], [[Belgium]]. It was established in 1817 by [[King William I of the Netherlands|King William I]] of the [[United Kingdom of the Netherlands|Netherlands]]. After the [[Belgian revolution]] of 1830, the newly formed Belgian state began to administer the university. In 1930, it became the first [[Dutch language|Dutch]]-speaking university in Belgium, whereas [[French language|French]] had previously been the standard academic language. In 1991, the university was granted major autonomy and changed its name accordingly from ''State University of Ghent'' ({{lang-nl|Rijksuniversiteit Gent}}, abbreviated as ''RUG'') to its current designation. In contrast to the [[Catholic University of Leuven (1835–1968)|Catholic University of Leuven]] or the [[Free University of Brussels]], UGent considers itself a ''pluralist'' university in a special sense, i.e. not connected to any particular religion or political ideology. Its motto '''Inter Utrumque''' ('In Between Both Extremes'), on the coat of arms, suggests the acquisition of wisdom and science comes only in an atmosphere of peace, when the institution is fully supported by the monarchy and fatherland. Ghent University is one of the biggest [[Flanders|Flemish]] universities, consisting of 41,000 students and 9,000 staff members. The University also supports the [[Ghent University Library|University Library]] and the [[Ghent University Hospital|University Hospital]], which is one of the largest hospitals in Belgium. It is one of the greatest beneficiaries of funding from the [[Research Foundation - Flanders (FWO)]]. Ghent University consistently rates among the top universities not only in Belgium but also throughout the world. == History == === Foundation, in the 19th century === The university in Ghent was opened on October 9, 1817, with JC van Rotterdam serving as the first [[Rector (academia)|rector]]. In the first year, it had 190 students and 16 professors. The original four faculties consisted of Humanities (Letters), Law, Medicine and Science, and the language of instruction was [[Latin]]. The university was founded by [[King William I of the Netherlands|King William I]] as part of a policy to stem the intellectual and academic lag in the southern part of the [[United Kingdom of the Netherlands]], later to become Belgium. After peaking at a student population of 414, the number of students declined quickly following the [[Belgian Revolution]]. At this time, the Faculties of Humanities and Science were broken from the university, but they were restored five years later, in 1835. Ghent University played a big role in the foundation of modern organic chemistry. Friedrich [[August Kekulé]] (7 September 1829 – 13 July 1896) unraveled the structure of benzene at Ghent and [[Adolf von Baeyer]] (Johann Friedrich Wilhelm Adolf von Baeyer), a student of [[August Kekulé]], made seminal contributions to organic chemistry. In 1882, Sidonie Verhelst became the first female student at the university. French became the language of instruction, taking the place of Latin, after the 1830 Revolution. In 1903, the Flemish politician [[Lodewijk De Raet]] led a successful campaign to begin instruction in [[Dutch language|Dutch]], and the first courses were begun in 1906. [[File:De plechtige installatie van de Universiteit van Gent door de prins van Oranje in de troonzaal van het stadhuis op 9 oktober 1817. Rijksmuseum SK-A-4088.jpeg|thumb|left|Painting of the establishment of the State University of Ghent in 1817 when the city was under Dutch rule]] === Developments since the 20th century === During [[World War I]], the occupying German administration conducted ''[[Flamenpolitik]]'' and turned Ghent University into the first Dutch-speaking university in Belgium. A Flemish Institute (''Vlaemsche Hoogeschool''), commonly known as [[Von Bissing University]], was founded in 1916 but was disestablished after the war and French language was fully reinstated. In 1923, Cabinet Minister [[Pierre Nolf]] put forward a motion to definitively establish the university as a Dutch-speaking university, and this was realized in 1930. [[August Vermeylen]] served as the first rector of a Dutch-language university in Belgium.[http://www.time.com/time/printout/0,8816,880570,00.html A Language Come Back], ''[[TIME Magazine]]'', April 28, 1923 In the [[World War II|Second World War]], the German administration of the university attempted to create a German orientation, removing faculty members and installing loyal activists. However, the university became the focal point for many resistance members as the war progressed. [[File:Ghent_University_1910_-_Studentenvereniging_Société_Académique_d'Histoire.jpg|thumb|Ghent University 1910 - Studentenvereniging Société Académique d'Histoire]] After the war, the university became a much larger institution, following government policy of democratizing higher education in Flanders during the 1950s and 1960s. By 1953, there were more than 3,000 students, and by 1969 more than 11,500. The number of faculties increased to eleven, starting with Applied Sciences in 1957. It was followed by Economics and Veterinary Medicine in 1968, Psychology and Pedagogy, as well as Bioengineering, in 1969, and Pharmaceutical Sciences. The faculty of Politics and Social Sciences is the most recent addition, in 1992. In the 1960s to 1980s, there were several [[student activism|student demonstrations]] at Ghent University, notably around the [[Blandijn]] site, which houses the Faculty of Arts & Philosophy.{{cite web | first = Fien | last = Danniau | title = Haard van verzet | publisher = UGent Memorie | url = http://www.ugentmemorie.be/artikel/haard-van-verzet | accessdate = January 10, 2012|language=nl}} The severest demonstrations took place in 1969 in the wake of [[May 1968 in France|May 1968]]. The university officially changed its name from ''Rijksuniversiteit Gent'' (RUG) to ''Universiteit Gent'' (UGent) in 1991 following an increased grant of autonomy by the government of the [[Flemish Community]]. In 2017, Rik Van de Walle succeeded Anne De Paepe as rector. ==Academic Profile== === Organisation and structure === Ghent University consists of eleven [[Faculty (division)|Faculties]] with over 130 individual departments. In addition, the university maintains the [[Zwijnaarde science park]] and [[Greenbridge science park]]. ==== List of faculties ==== [[File:Faculteitsbibliotheek_Letteren_en_Wijsbegeerte_UGent.jpg|thumb|Faculteitsbibliotheek Letteren en Wijsbegeerte UGent]] * Faculty of Arts and Philosophy{{cite web|url=http://www.flw.ugent.be/|title=Faculteit Letteren en Wijsbegeerte - Faculteit Letteren en Wijsbegeerte|last=Vervaeke|first=Ann|publisher=}} * Faculty of Bio-science Engineering{{cite web|url=http://www.flw.ugent.be|title=Faculteit Letteren en Wijsbegeerte - Faculteit Letteren en Wijsbegeerte|last=Vervaeke|first=Ann|publisher=}} * Faculty of Law{{cite web |url=http://www.law.ugent.be/en/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-04-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130406054819/http://www.law.ugent.be/en/ |archivedate=2013-04-06 |df= }} * Faculty of Sciences{{cite web|url=http://www.ugent.be/we/en|title=Faculty of Sciences — Ghent University|publisher=}} * Faculty of Medicine and Health Sciences{{cite web|url=http://www.ugent.be/ge/nl|title=Faculteit Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen — Universiteit Gent|publisher=}} * Faculty of Engineering and Architecture{{cite web|url=http://www.ugent.be/ea/en|title=Faculty of Engineering and Architecture — Ghent University|publisher=}} * Faculty of Economics and Business Administration{{cite web |url=http://www.feb.ugent.be/en/index.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-04-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130403000009/http://www.feb.ugent.be/en/index.asp |archivedate=2013-04-03 |df= }} * Faculty of Veterinary Medicine{{cite web|url=http://www.ugent.be/di/en|title=Faculty of Veterinary Medicine — Ghent University|publisher=}} * Faculty of Psychology and Educational Sciences{{cite web|url=http://www.fppw.ugent.be/|title=Faculteit Psychologie en Pedagoghische Wetenschappen (FPPW)|publisher=}} * Faculty of Pharmaceutical Sciences{{cite web|url=http://www.ugent.be/fw/en|title=Faculty of Pharmaceutical Sciences — Ghent University|publisher=}} * Faculty of Political and Social Sciences{{cite web|url=http://www.ugent.be/ps/en|title=Faculty of Political and Social Sciences — Ghent University|publisher=}} === Library === [[File:Ugent_boekentoren_675.jpg|thumb|Ugent boekentoren 675]] Standing on the [[Blandijnberg]], the [[Boekentoren]] houses the [[Ghent University Library]], which contains nearly 3 million volumes. The University Library has joined the [[Google Books Library Project]]. Among other notable collections, it preserves [[Papyrus 30]], an early manuscript of the Greek New Testament. ===Reputation & rankings=== Ghent University consistently ranks among the best universities in the world (top 100). Most recently, in 2017, it was ranked, globally, 69th by the [[Academic Ranking of World Universities]] (or Shanghai ranking){{cite web|url=http://www.shanghairanking.com/World-University-Rankings/Ghent-University.html|title=Shanghai Ranking 2017 Results|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} and 125th by ''[[QS World University Rankings]].''{{cite web|url=http://www.topuniversities.com/universities/ghent-university|title=QS Top Universities Ranking 2014-2015}} For 2018, Ghent University has been ranked, worldwide, 88th by [[U.S. News & World Report]]{{Cite web|url=https://www.usnews.com/education/best-global-universities/ghent-university-506883|title=Best Global Universities 2018|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} and 107th by ''[[Times Higher Education]].''{{cite web|url=https://www.timeshighereducation.com/world-university-rankings/ghent-university|title=The Times Higher Education World University Rankings 2014-2015|publisher=timeshighereducation.com}} ===International relations=== The university maintains many partnerships within Belgium, across Europe, and throughout the world. For instance, Ghent University supports the [[Belgian Co-ordinated Collections of Micro-organisms]] and the [[Vlaams Instituut voor Biotechnologie]]. Within Europe, it is a member of the [[Santander Network]] and the U4 Network. It also participates in the [[Conference of European Schools for Advanced Engineering Education and Research]]. In addition, the University cooperates with numerous universities for the [[Erasmus Programme|Erasmus]] and [[Erasmus Mundus]] programs; within the framework of the latter, it heads the [[International Master of Science in Rural Development]]. Outside of Europe, Ghent University conducts exchange programs on all six continents.{{cite web|url=https://www.ugent.be/student/nl/studeren/tijdens/bestemmingen.htm|title=Bestemmingen — Studentenportaal — Universiteit Gent|publisher=ugent.be}} ===Associated contributions and innovations=== Ghent University has been instrumental in the development of [[COinS]] and [[Unipept]]. == People == File:Johan Heinrich Neuman - Johan Rudolf Thorbecke.jpg|Johan Rudolf Thorbecke, statesman File:Henry.Pirenne.Portrait.gif|Henri Pirenne, historian File:George de Hevesy.jpg|George de Hevesy, Nobel Prize winner in Chemistry File:Maurice Maeterlinck 2.jpg|Maurice Maeterlinck, Nobel Prize winner in Literature File:Corneille Heymans nobel.jpg|Corneille Heymans, Nobel Prize winner in Medicine File:Belgisch-Nederlandse studieconferentie te Helvoirt (NB). revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2015}} {{Use Indian English|date=December 2015}} {{BLP sources|date=January 2016}} [[File:Main-qimg-97cd7e03a7d18b8e463be1d4b800906c-c.jpg|thumb]] {{Infobox scientist | name = Harish Chandra Verma | image = | image_size = 29 KB | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1952|04|03|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Darbhanga ]] [[Bihar]] | nationality = [[India]]n | alma_mater = [[Patna Science College]], [[Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur]] | doctoral_advisor = Prof. GN Rao | known_for = Concepts of Physics Vol. I & II | website = http://www.hcverma.in/ | field = [[Nuclear physics]] }} '''Harish Chandra Verma''' (born 3 April 1952) is an Indian [[experimental physicist]] and a retired professor at the [[Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur]] since 1994. His field of research is [[nuclear physics]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://iitk.ac.in/new/h-c-verma | title=Profile of DR. H. C. Verma | publisher=''Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur'' | accessdate=2 April 2016}}</ref>
He has authored several books on physics at the graduate, undergraduate and school levels. His most popular work is the two-volume book ''[[Concepts of Physics]]''. He has co-founded initiatives like ''Shiksha Sopan'' for the social upliftment of the children of the economically weaker section living near the IITK campus.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.tribuneindia.com/2014/20140831/spectrum/main2.htm | title=Spreading the light of knowledge | date=31 August 2014 | accessdate=19 September 2014 |publisher=''[[The Tribune (Chandigarh)|The Tribune]]''}}</ref> According to his website, he is currently working on a book dealing with [[electrostatics]], [[magnetostatics]] and [[electrodynamics]] at the undergraduate level.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://home.iitk.ac.in/~hcverma/Bookunderpub.htm|title=Electromechanics|publisher=iitk.ac.in|website=HC Verma's webpage}}</ref>
==Early education== H. C. Verma spent most of his childhood in [[Patna]] and this can be reflected in some texts in his book. He was trained in basic arithmetic by his father Shri Ganesh Prasad Verma, a teacher. Verma has been through the sweet and sour experiences of India's school education system, and this gave him low interest towards studies throughout his school years; until high school, due to which he even struggled to pass his exams. After he graduated high school, he entered [[Patna Science College]], which was a place that moulded this normal school boy into a confident and bright adolescent.<ref name="biography">{{cite web|last1=Singh|first1=Jitender|title=Biography of Dr. H. C. Verma|url=http://www.concepts-of-physics.com/dr-hc-verma/biography.php|website=www.concepts-of-physics.com|accessdate=2 April 2016}}</ref>
==Formative years==
Patna Science College's environment was totally different than his former school. The teachers were bright, enthusiastic and encouraging. As a student who struggled for passing marks was changed into a third place student in Patna University, receiving a B.Sc. (Honours) degree in Physics. From 1975 to 1977, Verma joined the IIT Kanpur for a M.Sc. and was placed as a top student with a performance index of 9.9 out of 10.0. He then chose to remain at IIT Kanpur for his doctorate. Verma received a PhD degree in less than three years.
==Career==
===Patna Science College=== In 1980, Verma joined the reputed [[Patna Science College]] as a lecturer. He remained in Patna Science college as a lecturer and reader for 15 years before coming to [[IIT Kanpur]].
===IIT Kanpur===
Dr. Verma joined IIT Kanpur in 1994 as assistant professor. Here, he taught many courses, guided M. Sc. and PhD students, authored a book "Quantum Physics", and pursued research in experimental nuclear physics. While at IIT Kanpur, apart from his regular assignments, he took many socio-educational initiatives for the benefit of education and society. Some of these initiatives are [http://home.iitk.ac.in/~hcverma/Introduction.htm School Physics Project], [http://www.shiksha-sopan.org/ Siksha Sopan], and [http://www.utsahiphysicsteachers.com/ Utsahi Physics Teachers]. He retired from formal teaching on 30 June 2017, after 38 years in Teaching Physics.
===Publications=== He has published 139 research papers for various journals. He has also written several books on Physics for school and intermediate levels. Of these, Concepts of Physics has become a widely known and recommended book on the subject.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Verma|first1=H C|url=http://www.hcverma.in/ReadMore|website=H C Verma|accessdate=10 April 2018|title=Prof. H C Verma}}</ref>
==Bibliography== * ''Concepts of Physics Part-1'', Bharati Bhawan Publishers & Distributors, 1992, {{ISBN|8177091875}} * ''Concepts of Physics Part-2'', Bharati Bhawan Publishers & Distributors, 1992, {{ISBN|8177092324}} * ''Quantum Physics'', Surya Publication, {{ISBN|9788192571409}} * ''Foundation Science Physics for class 9'', Bharati Bhawan Publishers & Distributors, {{ISBN|9788177097313}} * ''Foundation Science Physics for class 10'', Bharati Bhawan Publishers & Distributors, {{ISBN|9350270064}}

{{Use Indian English|date=July 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} [[File:IIT Kharagpur Main Building.JPG|thumb|upright|300px|Institute Main Building of the [[Indian Institute of Technology Kharagpur]] (IIT KGP) in the city of [[Kharagpur]] ([[West Bengal]])]]
[[Image:IIM Panorama Ahmedabad.JPG|thumb|300px|upright|[[Indian Institute of Management Ahmedabad|Indian Institute of Management]], [[Ahmedabad]] ([[Gujarat]])]] [[File:IIM Calcutta Auditorium 1.jpg|thumb|border|upright|300px|alt=IIM Calcutta's Auditorium|The Auditorium at [[Indian Institute of Management Calcutta]], in the city of [[Kolkata]] ([[West Bengal]]).]]
India's higher education system is the third largest in the world, next to the [[Higher education in the United States|United States]] and [[Higher education in China|China]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://siteresources.worldbank.org/EDUCATION/Resources/278200-1121703274255/1439264-1193249163062/India_CountrySummary.pdf|title=India Country Summary of Higher Education|publisher=World Bank}}</ref> The main governing body at the [[Tertiary education|tertiary level]] is the [[University Grants Commission (India)|University Grants Commission]], which enforces its standards, advises the government, and helps coordinate between the centre and the state.<ref name=I09RA-237/> Accreditation for higher learning is overseen by 15 autonomous institutions established by the [[University Grants Commission (India)|University Grants Commission]] (UGC) .<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.education.nic.in/higedu.asp |title=''Higher Education'', National Informatics Centre, Government of India |publisher=Education.nic.in |date= |accessdate=2010-09-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718071823/http://www.education.nic.in/higedu.asp |archivedate=18 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
As per the latest [[2011 Census of India|2011 Census]], about 8.15% (68 millions) of Indians are graduates, with [[Union Territories]] of [[Chandigarh]] and [[Delhi]] topping the list with 24.65% and 22.56% of their population being graduates respectively.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/only-815-of-indians-are-graduates-census-data-show/article7496655.ece |title= Only 8.15% of Indians are graduates, Census data show |work=[[The Hindu]] |date=2015-08-04 |accessdate=2016-04-01|author=Rukmini S.}}</ref> Indian higher education system has expanded at a fast pace by adding nearly 20,000 colleges and more than 8 million students in a decade from 2000–01 to 2010–11.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dreducation.com/2012/06/latest-statistics-indian-higher.html |title=Latest Statistics on Indian Higher Education |publisher=DrEducation.com |date=2012-07-17 |accessdate=2012-08-28}}</ref> {{As of|2016}}, India has 799 universities, with a break up of 44 [[Central university, India|central universities]], 540 [[State university (India)|state universities]], 122 [[Deemed university|deemed universities]], 90 [[Private university (India)|private universities]], 5 institutions established and functioning under the State Act, and 75 [[Institutes of National Importance ]]which include AIIMS, IITs, IIEST and NITs among others.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://mhrd.gov.in/sites/upload_files/mhrd/files/statistics/AISHE2015-16.pdf|title=Statistics – Ministry of Human Resource Development|last=|first=|date=|website=mhrd.gov.in|access-date=}}</ref><ref name=I09RA-237>''India 2009: A Reference Annual (53rd edition)'', 237</ref><ref name=Central>{{cite web |url= http://www.ugc.ac.in/inside/centraluni.html |title=Central Universities |work=ugc.ac.in |accessdate=6 June 2011}}</ref><ref name=State>{{cite web|url=http://www.ugc.ac.in/inside/StateUniv_total.pdf|title=List of State Universities|date=27 May 2011|accessdate=2011-06-06|format=PDF}}</ref><ref name=Deemed>{{cite web|url=http://www.ugc.ac.in/inside/deemeduniv.html |title=:::Deemed University – University Grants Commission ::: |work=ugc.ac.in |date=23 June 2008 |accessdate=6 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101129070530/http://www.ugc.ac.in/inside/deemeduniv.html |archivedate=29 November 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name=Private>{{cite web|url=http://www.ugc.ac.in/inside/privateuniversity.html |title=:::Private Universities – University Grants Commission ::: |work=ugc.ac.in |date=1 August 2011 |accessdate=1 August 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60c80MqjF?url=http://www.ugc.ac.in/inside/privateuniversity.html |archivedate=1 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name=nic>{{cite web|url=http://www.education.nic.in/IHL/INSTITUTESNATIONALIMPORTANCE.pdf |title=The Institutes of National Importance |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091007072436/http://www.education.nic.in/IHL/INSTITUTESNATIONALIMPORTANCE.pdf |archivedate=7 October 2009 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Other institutions include 39,071 colleges as [[Government Degree Colleges, India|Government Degree Colleges]] and Private Degree Colleges, including 1800 exclusive women's colleges, functioning under these universities and institutions as reported by the UGC in 2016.<ref name=":0" /> Colleges may be Autonomous, i.e. empowered to examine their own degrees, up to [[PhD]] level in some cases, or non-autonomous, in which case their examinations are under the supervision of the university to which they are affiliated; in either case, however, degrees are awarded in the name of the university rather than the college.
The emphasis in the tertiary level of education lies on science and technology.<ref name=Blackwell95-96>Blackwell, 95–96</ref> Indian educational institutions by 2004 consisted of a large number of technology institutes.<ref name=Blackwell96/> Distance learning and open education is also a feature of the Indian higher education system, and is looked after by the [[Distance Education Council]].<ref name=Blackwell96>Blackwell, 96</ref> [[Indira Gandhi National Open University]] is the largest university in the world by number of students, having approximately 3.5 million students across the globe.<ref>{{cite web|author=National Network of Education |url=http://indiaedunews.net/Universities/%27Mobile_Study_Centres_have_increased_student_participation%27_-_IGNOU_VC_6243/ |title=‘Mobile Study Centres have increased student participation’ – IGNOU VC, Universities News – By |publisher=Indiaedunews.net |date=2008-10-06 |accessdate=2011-05-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.education4india.com/category/ignou/ |title=» Ignou :: Education, Careers & Professional News |publisher=News.education4india.com |date= |accessdate=2011-05-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ignou.ac.in/ignou/aboutignou/profile/2 |title=Profile of IGNOU – Preamble |publisher=Ignou.ac.in |date= |accessdate=2011-05-03 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141216183845/http://www.ignou.ac.in/ignou/aboutignou/profile/2 |archive-date=16 December 2014 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Some institutions of India, such as the [[Indian Institutes of Technology]] (IITs), [[Indian Institute of Engineering Science and Technology, Shibpur|Indian Institute of Engineering Science and Technology]] (IIEST), [[National Institute of Technology|National Institutes of Technology]] (NITs), [[Indian Institute of Science]], [[Indian Institutes of Science Education and Research|Indian Institute of Science Education and Research]]<ref name=":1" />(IISERs), [[University of Delhi]] (DI), [[Indian Institutes of Management]] (IIMs), [[University of Calcutta]], [[University of Mumbai]] and [[Jawaharlal Nehru University, Delhi|Jawaharlal Nehru University]] have been globally acclaimed for their standard of education.<ref name=Blackwell96/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/the-worlds-best-engineering-schools-2012-6?IR=T#41-university-of-mumbai-10|title=The World's Best Engineering Schools|author=Matt Lynley|date=9 July 2012|work=Business Insider}}</ref><ref name="topuniversities.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.topuniversities.com/university-rankings/brics-rankings/2013#sorting=rank+country=+stars=false+search=|title=QS University Rankings: BRICS 2013|work=Top Universities}}</ref><ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite web|url=http://www.topuniversities.com/university-rankings-articles/brics-rankings/top-universities-india|title=Top Universities in India|work=Top Universities}}</ref> The IITs enroll about 8000 students annually and the alumni have contributed to both the growth of the private sector and the public sectors of India. However, Indian universities still lag behind universities such as [[Harvard University|Harvard]], [[Cambridge University|Cambridge]], and [[Oxford University|Oxford]].<ref name=times>[http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2010-09-17/india/28220501_1_qs-world-university-rankings-three-rankings-academic-ranking India doesn't figure in world top-100 universities], ''Press Trust of India'' via ''timesofindia.com'', 2010-09-12</ref>
Indian higher education is in need of radical reforms. A focus on enforcing higher standards of transparency,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.universityworldnews.com/article.php?story=20140522105636511|title=Reforming higher education with transparency – University World News|website=www.universityworldnews.com|access-date=2016-06-28}}</ref> strengthening of the vocational and doctoral education pipeline, and professionalization of the sector through stronger institutional responsibility would help in reprioritizing efforts and working around the complexities.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dreducation.com/2014/05/reform-higher-education-system-india.html|title=Three Solutions for Reforming Indian Higher Education ~ DrEducation: Global Higher Education Research|last=Choudaha|first=Rahul|website=www.dreducation.com|access-date=2016-06-28}}</ref> The rise of IT sector and engineering education in India has boxed students into linear path without giving them a chance to explore and discover their passions. Concerted and collaborative efforts are needed in broaden student choices through liberal arts education.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dreducation.com/2015/05/engineering-liberal-arts-India.html|title=Why India should go beyond engineering and diversify with liberal arts education? ~ DrEducation: Global Higher Education Research|last=Choudaha|first=Rahul|website=www.dreducation.com|access-date=2016-06-28}}</ref>
== History == India is believed to have had a functioning system of higher education as early as 1000 B.C.<ref name=":02">{{Cite journal|last=Chitnis|first=Suma|date=Feb 3, 2000|title=Higher Education in India|url=https://search.proquest.com/docview/194193481?accountid=14496|journal=Black Issues in Higher Education|volume=16|pages=28|via=ProQuest}}</ref> Unlike present day universities, these ancient learning centers were primarily concerned with dispersing Vedic education.<ref name=":12">{{Cite book|url=https://link.springer.com/book/10.1057/978-1-137-53571-9|title=A History of the Indian University System {{!}} SpringerLink|last=Datta|first=Surja|language=en-gb|doi=10.1057/978-1-137-53571-9}}</ref> The modern Indian education system finds its roots in colonial legacy.<ref name=":22">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dNKcOxvwfV0C&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q=history%20of%20higher%20education%20in%20India|title=History and Development of Higher Education in India|last=Sharma|first=Shaloo|date=2002|publisher=Sarup & Sons|isbn=9788176253185|language=en}}</ref> The British Government used the university system as a tool of cultural colonization.<ref name=":02" /> Colonial efforts in higher education were carried out initially through the [[East India Company]], followed by the British parliament and later under direct British rule.<ref name=":12" /> The first institution of higher learning set up by the British East India Company was the Calcutta Madrasa in 1781. This was followed by the [[The Asiatic Society|Asiatic Society]] of Bengal in 1784, Benaras Sanskrit College in 1791 and [[Fort William College]] in 1800.<ref name=":22"/><ref name=":12" /> With the Charter Act of 1813, the British Parliament officially declared Indian education as one of the duties of the state.<ref name=":22"/> The same act also removed restrictions on missionary work in British India, thus leading to the establishment of the evangelist Serampore College in 1818.<ref name=":12" /> [[Thomas Babington Macaulay|Thomas Babbington Macaulay’]]<nowiki/>s famously controversial Minute on Education (1835) reflected the growing support of a Western approach to knowledge over an Oriental one.<ref name=":12" /> Soon after, in 1857, the first three official universities were started in Bombay (Mumbai), Calcutta (Kolkata) and Madras (Chennai). These universities were modeled after the University of London and focused on English and the humanities<ref name=":4">{{Cite book|url=https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-1-4020-4012-2_38|title=International Handbook of Higher Education|last=Jayaram|first=N.|date=2007|publisher=Springer, Dordrecht|isbn=9781402040115|series=Springer International Handbooks of Education|pages=747–767|language=en|doi=10.1007/978-1-4020-4012-2_38.pdf}}</ref>
The British control of the Indian education system continued until the [[Government of India Act, 1935|Government of India Act of 1935]] that transferred more power to provincial politicians and began the "Indianisation" of education. This period witnessed a rise in the importance of physical and vocational education as well as the introduction of basic education schemes.<ref name=":22"/> When India gained independence in 1947, the nation had a total of 241,369 students registered across 20 universities and 496 colleges. In 1948, the Indian Government established the University Education Commission to oversee the growth and improvement of higher education.<ref name=":4" /> In the 1960s and 1970s, the government increased its efforts to support higher education by not only setting up state-funded universities and colleges, but also providing financial assistance to private institutions, resulting in the creation of private aided/ grant-in-aid institutions.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Agarwal|first=Pawan|date=2007-04-01|title=Higher Education in India: Growth, Concerns and Change Agenda|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1468-2273.2007.00346.x/abstract|journal=Higher Education Quarterly|language=en|volume=61|issue=2|pages=197–207|doi=10.1111/j.1468-2273.2007.00346.x|issn=1468-2273}}</ref>
Despite the leave of the British, Indian higher education continued to give importance to the languages and humanities until the 1980s. Institutes of professional education like the Indian Institutes of Technology (IITs), Regional Engineering Colleges (REC) and Indian Institutes of Management (IIM) were some of the more prominent exceptions to this trend. These institutions drew inspiration from reputed universities in the United States and also received foreign funding. Post 1980s, the changing needs of the economy, a growing middle class and an increased strain on government financial resources, slowed the growth of state-funded higher educational institutions. This led to an increased role of the private sector in the education system.<ref name=":3" />
==Universities== {{see also|University Grants Commission (India)}} Universities in India have evolved in divergent streams with each stream monitored by an apex body, indirectly controlled by the [[Ministry of Human Resource Development (India)|Ministry of Human Resource Development]] and funded jointly by the state governments. There are Most universities are administered by the States, however, there are 18 important universities called Central Universities, which are maintained by the Union Government. The increased funding of the central universities give them an advantage over their state competitors.
The University Grants Commission estimated that in 2013–14, 22,849 PhDs and 20,425 MPhil degrees were awarded. Over half of these were in the fields of Science, Engineering/Technology, Medicine and Agriculture. {{as of|2014}}–15, over 178,000 students were enrolled in research programs.<ref>http://www.ugc.ac.in/pdfnews/2465555_Annual-Report-2014-15.pdf</ref>
Apart from the several hundred state universities, there is a network of research institutions that provide opportunities for advanced learning and research leading up to a PhD in branches of science, technology and agriculture. Several have won international recognition.
25 of these institutions come under the umbrella of the CSIR – Council of Scientific and Industrial Research and over 60 fall under the ICAR – Indian Council of Agricultural Research. In addition, the DAE – Department of Atomic Energy, and other ministries support various research laboratories.
The [[National Institutes of Technology|National Institute of Technology]] (NITs), [[Indian Institutes of Information Technology]] (IIITs), [[Indian Institute of Technology|Indian Institutes of Technology]] are among the most prestigious institutions within the technology sciences. [[Indian Institute of Science]] (IISc) and [[Indian Institutes of Science Education and Research|Indian Institute of Science Education and Research]]<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|date=2015-03-26|title=India|url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v519/n7544_supp_ni/full/519S66a.html|journal=Nature|language=en|volume=519|issue=7544|pages=S66–S67|doi=10.1038/519S66a|issn=0028-0836}}</ref>(IISERs) are the premier research institutes in the field of science education and research. There are several thousand colleges (affiliated to different universities) that provide undergraduate science, agriculture, commerce and humanities courses in India. Amongst these, the best also offer post graduate courses while some also offer facilities for research and PhD studies.
Technical education has grown rapidly in recent years. Of 27.3 million students enrolled in undergraduate studies, about 4.5 million are in engineering fields.<ref name=":0" /> With recent capacity additions, it now appears that the nation has the capability to graduate over 500,000 engineers (with 4-yr undergraduate degrees) annually, and there is also a corresponding increase in the graduation of computer scientists (roughly 50,000 with post-graduate degree). In addition, the nation graduates over 1.2 million scientists. Furthermore, each year, the nation is enrolling at least 350,000 in its engineering diploma programs (with plans to increase this by about 50,000). Thus, India's annual enrollment of scientists, engineers and technicians now exceeds 2 million.
Across the country, tertiary enrollment rates have increased at a [[compound annual growth rate]] of 3.5% in the 5 years preceding 2016. Current enrollment stands at 34.58 million, over 15% more than the 29.2 million enrolled in 2011.<ref name=":0" />
International league tables produced in 2006 by the London-based [[Times Higher Education Supplement]](THES) confirmed [[Jawaharlal Nehru University, Delhi|Jawaharlal Nehru University]] (JNU)'s place among the world's top 200 universities.<ref>THES, "The World's Top 200 Universities", The Times Higher Education Supplement, 6 October 2006. {{cite web |url=http://www.thes.co.uk/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-08-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080111133147/http://www.thes.co.uk/ |archivedate=11 January 2008 |df=dmy-all }} (Subscription is necessary to get access to much of THES content)</ref> Likewise, [[Times Higher Education|THES]] 2006 ranked JNU's School of Social Sciences<ref>THES, "Top 100 in Social Sciences", The Times Higher Education Supplement, 27 October 2006.</ref> at the 57th position among the world's top 100 institutes for social sciences. In 2017, THES ranked the [[Indian Institute of Science]] as the eighth best "small university" in the world. A small university was defined as one with less than 5000 students. In 2015, the institute also became the first Indian institute to make it to the top hundred in the THES list of engineering institutes. It was ranked 99.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/home/education/iisc-becomes-1st-indian-university-to-be-ranked-among-top-10-in-world/articleshow/57504702.cms|title=IISc becomes first Indian university to be ranked among top 10 in world – Times of India|work=The Times of India|access-date=2017-03-10}}</ref>
The [[Anna University]], which is of the affiliated type, is a member of the [[Association of Indian Universities]], the [[Association of Commonwealth Universities]] and Partner of UNESCO International Center for Engineering Education (UICEE). [[University Grants Commission (India)|UGC]] have accredited Anna University with Five Star Status in 2002 which is the highest rating. With proven capabilities both in academic and research areas, Anna University was able to receive this honour for a period of five years for excellence in technical education.
The [[University of Calcutta]] was the first multi-disciplinary university of modern India. According to The Times Higher Education Supplement's survey of the world's top arts and humanities universities, dated November 10, 2005, this university, ranked 39, was the only Indian university to make it to the top 50 list in that year. Other research institutes are the [[Saha Institute of Nuclear Physics]], the [[Asiatic Society]], and the [[Indian Statistical Institute]].
The [[National Law School of India University]] is highly regarded, with some of its students being awarded [[Rhodes Scholarship]]s to [[Oxford University]], and the [[All India Institute of Medical Sciences]] is consistently rated the top medical school in the country.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.outlookindia.com/full.asp?fodname=20070611&fname=APemchand+Palety&sid=2 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120908022718/http://www.outlookindia.com/full.asp?fodname=20070611&fname=APemchand+Palety&sid=2 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-09-08 |title=outlookindia.com – more than just the news magazine from India |work=outlookindia.com/ }}</ref> [[Indian Institutes of Management|Indian Institutes of Management (IIMs)]] are the top management institutes in India.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.outlookindia.com/full.asp?fodname=20080929&fname=ALead+Essay&sid=2 |title=outlookindia.com – more than just the news magazine from India |work=outlookindia.com/ |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080925224453/http://www.outlookindia.com/full.asp?fodname=20080929&fname=ALead+Essay&sid=2 |archivedate=25 September 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
The private sector is strong in Indian higher education. This has been partly as a result of the decision by the Government to divert spending to the goal of universalisation of elementary education. Within a decade different state assemblies have passed bills for private universities, including [[Birla Institute of Technology and Science]], [[Institute of Finance and International Management]], [[XLRI|Xavier Labour Relations Institute]], [[ICFAI University, Dehradun]], [[O. P. Jindal Global University]] and many more.
India is also the leading source of international students around the world. More than 200,000 Indian students are studying abroad. They are likely to be enrolled in master's programs with engineering focus which provide them opportunities to enhance career potential.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://resources.interedge.org/2016/01/18/indian-students-career-us-stem-opt-master/|title=Three ways Indian students maximize the career potential in the US higher education|last=Choudaha|first=Rahul|last2=Hu|first2=Di|date=2016-01-18|website=interEDGE.org|publisher=DrEducation|access-date=2016-06-28}}</ref>
===Accreditation=== Indian law requires that universities be accredited unless created through an act of Parliament. Without accreditation, the government notes, "These fake institutions have no legal entity to call themselves as University/Vishwvidyalaya and to award ‘degree’ which are not treated as valid for academic/employment purposes."<ref name="cu">{{cite web|url=http://www.education.nic.in/htmlweb/he-centraluniversities-list.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061009183806/http://www.education.nic.in/htmlweb/he-centraluniversities-list.htm|title=Central Universities|archivedate=9 October 2006|publisher=}}</ref> [https://web.archive.org/web/20071229114428/http://www.ugc.ac.in/policy/ugcact1956.html The University Grants Commission Act 1956] explains, <blockquote>"the right of conferring or granting degrees shall be exercised only by a University established or incorporated by or under a Central Act carlo bon tempo, or a State Act, or an Institution deemed to be University or an institution specially empowered by an Act of the Parliament to confer or grant degrees. Thus, any institution which has not been created by an enactment of Parliament or a State Legislature or has not been granted the status of a Deemed to be University, is not entitled to award a degree."<ref name="cu" /></blockquote>
Accreditation for higher learning is overseen by autonomous institutions established by the [[University Grants Commission (India)|University Grants Commission]]:<ref>[http://www.education.nic.in/higedu.asp Higher Education] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718071823/http://www.education.nic.in/higedu.asp |date=18 July 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ugc.ac.in/page/Professional-Councils.aspx#rehab|title=University Grants commission ::Professional Councils|website=www.ugc.ac.in|access-date=2018-08-09}}</ref>
* [[All India Council for Technical Education]] (AICTE) * [[Distance Education Council]] (DEC) * [[Indian Council of Agricultural Research]] (ICAR) * [[Bar Council of India]] (BCI) * [[National Assessment and Accreditation Council]] (NAAC) * [[National Council for Teacher Education]] (NCTE) * [[Rehabilitation Council of India]] (RCI) * [[Medical Council of India]] (MCI) * [[Pharmacy Council of India]] (PCI) * [[Indian Nursing Council]] (INC) * [[Dental Council of India]] (DCI) * [[Central Council of Homeopathy]] (CCH) * [[Central Council of Indian Medicine]] (CCIM) * [[Veterinary Council of India]] (VCI) * [[Rehabilitation Council of India]] (RCI) The issue of assessing and assuring quality of Indian higher education is a challenge. Instead of aiming for 'world-class' universities<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dreducation.com/2010/10/india-world-class-universities.html|title=Why does India lack world-class universities? ~ DrEducation: Global Higher Education Research|last=Choudaha|first=Rahul|publisher=DrEducation|access-date=2016-06-28}}</ref> through rankings, policy framework must improve the processes that enable accountability through data collection and reporting on parameters of institutional quality.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.universityworldnews.com/article.php?story=20160503182610693|title=Rankings should be used to increase quality for all – University World News|last=Dietrich|first=Erich|last2=Choudaha|first2=Rahul|publisher=University World News|access-date=2016-06-28}}</ref> The government should leverage this tool to improve quality of the overall system.
A study was done on autonomous colleges by the Centre for Public Policy Research (CPPR) in Kerala recommended that grading should be done for such institutions to improve their overall performance.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/kochi/Autonomous-yes-but-no-freedom-for-colleges/articleshow/54727281.cms|title=Autonomous yes, but no freedom for colleges – Times of India|work=The Times of India|access-date=2017-10-02}}</ref>
===Graduation market=== This is a chart of<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.censusindia.gov.in/ |title=Census of India Website : Office of the Registrar General & Census Commissioner |publisher= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5Xlqrcsme?url=http://www.censusindia.gov.in/ |archivedate=12 May 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> India as per Census 2001. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Degree || Holders |- | '''Total''' || '''37,670,147''' |- | Post-graduate degree other than technical degree || 6,949,707 |- | Graduate degree other than technical degree || 25,666,044 |- | Engineering and technology || 2,588,405 |- | Teaching || 1,547,671 |- | Medicine || 768,964**** |- | Agriculture and dairying || 100,126 |- | Veterinary || 99,999 |- | Other || 22,588 |}
== Administration == The institutional framework of higher education in India consists of Universities and Colleges.<ref name=":10">[http://www.iiste.org/Journals/index.php/JEP/article/viewFile/1146/1067 Gupta], Deepti, Navneet Gupta, and Mandir Marg. “Higher Education in India: Structure, Statistics and Challenges.” ''Journal of Education and Practice'' 3, no. 2 (2012): 9.</ref> As reported in 2015, India has 760 universities and 38,498 colleges.<ref>MHRD, [http://mhrd.gov.in/sites/upload_files/mhrd/files/document-reports/AR_2015-16%20ENGLISH.pdf Annual Report on Higher Education in India- 2015-2016].</ref> There are three types of universities: Conventional Universities, Deemed Universities and Institutions of National Importance.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ranjan Ravi|first=Naveen|date=2015|title="Structure and Organisation of Higher Education in India : A Macro-Perspective"|url=http://ccemohali.org/img/Ch%203%20Dr%20Naveen.pdf|journal=Indian Journal of Educational Studies : An Interdisciplinary Journal|volume=2|pages=|via=}}</ref> While Conventional Universities are established through Act of Parliament or State Legislatures, Deemed Universities award degrees through the notification of the central government. Institutes of National Importance are those that have been awarded the status by Parliament.<ref name=":10" />
The education system of India falls broadly under the [[Ministry of Human Resource Development]](MHRD). Amongst the branches of the MHRD, the Department of Higher Education is responsible for overseeing the growth of the higher education sector. The Department aims to improve quality of and access to higher education for all sections of the population.<ref name=":11">{{Cite web|url=http://mhrd.gov.in/overview|title=About Department Of Higher Education {{!}} Government of India, Ministry of Human Resource Development|website=mhrd.gov.in|language=en|access-date=2018-03-14}}</ref> One of the key objectives of the Department is to increase the Gross Enrolment Ratio (GER) in higher education to 30% by 2020. Some of the other objectives of the department include: expansion of institutional base, greater inclusion of minorities, removal of regional disparities, infrastructural improvement and increased global participation.<ref name=":11" />
Current government initiatives include:
* '''Rashtriya Uchattar Shiksha Abhiyan''' - A total of 316 state public universities and 13,024 colleges will be covered under the Rashtriya Uchattar Shiksha Abhiyan, a plan to manage funding for higher education.<ref>{{cite web|title=Govt launches Rashtriya Uchchatar Shiksha Abhiyan for bouldering Higher Education|url=http://news.biharprabha.com/2013/10/govt-launches-rashtriya-uchchatar-shiksha-abhiyan-for-bouldering-higher-education/|accessdate=7 October 2013}}</ref> This is a scheme to develop state university by central govt funding (60% for general category states, 90% for special category states, 100% for union territories). * '''Scheme of Integrating Persons With Disabilities In The Mainstream Of Technical And Vocational Education''' - Caters to around 50 polytechnics in the country and provides them with grants-in-aid aimed at facilitating greater integration of disabled individuals into higher education.<ref name=":04">{{Cite web|url=http://mhrd.gov.in/higher_education|title=Department of Higher Education {{!}} Government of India, Ministry of Human Resource Development|website=mhrd.gov.in|language=en|access-date=2018-04-27}}</ref> * '''Scheme of Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya National Mission on Teachers and Teaching (PMMMNMTT)''' - The purpose of this scheme is to raise the quantity and quality of teaching staff across schools and colleges. It also aims to create better institutional frameworks in order to cultivate change in the positive direction.<ref name=":04" />
== Rankings == {{expand_section|date=August 2012}} {{update|date=July 2017}} University rankings are used to measure and compare institutional quality based on a range of indicators related to research, reputation and teaching.[http://theconversation.com/what-do-world-university-rankings-actually-mean-32355] Indian government's National Institutional Ranking Framework, or NIRF is the mechanism for measuring quality and also intended to determine funding and world-class university endeavors.[http://www.universityworldnews.com/article.php?story=20160503182610693] The "Institutions of Eminence (IoE)" initiative by the Government of India aims to build top-ranked Indian universities by providing autonomy and funding (only for public universities) and identified six institutions.[https://drive.google.com/file/d/1TkV2c0f8JoQKrL7Rr9d7rL1tuqvkJv8J/view]
The [[University of Mumbai]] was ranked 41 among the Top 50 Engineering Schools of the world by America's news broadcasting firm [[Business Insider]] in 2012 and was the only university in the list from the five emerging BRICS nations viz Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/the-worlds-best-engineering-schools-2012-6?IR=T|title=The World's Best Engineering Schools|author=Matt Lynley|date=9 July 2012|work=Business Insider}}</ref> It was ranked at 62 in the QS BRICS University rankings for 2013<ref name="topuniversities.com" /> and was India's 3rd best [[Interdisciplinarity|Multi Disciplinary]] University in the QS University ranking of Indian Universities after [[University of Calcutta]] and [[Delhi University]].<ref name="ReferenceA" /> Three Indian universities were listed in the [[Times Higher Education]] list of the world's top 200 universities — [[Indian Institutes of Technology]], [[Indian Institutes of Management]], and [[Jawaharlal Nehru University, Delhi|Jawaharlal Nehru University]] in 2005 and 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/hybrid.asp?typeCode=161 |title=Times Higher Education |publisher=Times Higher Education |date=2006-10-06 |accessdate=2010-09-01}}</ref> Six Indian Institutes of Technology and the [[Birla Institute of Technology and Science]] – Pilani were listed among the top 20 science and technology schools in Asia by ''[[Asiaweek]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www-cgi.cnn.com/ASIANOW/asiaweek/features/universities2000/scitech/sci.overall.html |title=Asia's Best Science and Technology Schools |publisher=Cgi.cnn.com |date=2000-06-22 |accessdate=2010-09-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/684WxRCIT?url=http://www-cgi.cnn.com/ASIANOW/asiaweek/features/universities2000/scitech/sci.overall.html |archivedate=31 May 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The [[Indian School of Business]] situated in [[Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh|Hyderabad]] was ranked number 12 in global MBA rankings by the ''[[Financial Times]]'' of London in 2010<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rankings.ft.com/businessschoolrankings/global-mba-rankings |title=MBA global Top 100 rankings – FT |publisher=ft.com |date= |accessdate=2009-03-04}}</ref> while the [[All India Institute of Medical Sciences]] has been recognised as a global leader in medical research and treatment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsweek.com/id/45114 |title=Medical Meccas: An Oasis for India's Poorest | Newsweek Health for Life | Newsweek.com |publisher=Newsweek.com |date= |accessdate=2008-11-03}}</ref> The [[Quacquarelli Symonds]] (QS) [[QS World University Rankings|World University Rankings]] published in 2013 ranked [[IIT Delhi]] at number 222 with a 49.4% score, [[IIT Bombay]] at 233, and [[IIT Kanpur]] at 295. No Indian universities appear in the top 200 worldwide except [[IISC Bangalore]] which is ranked at 147.<ref>{{Cite news|title=A study in apathy |date=September 11, 2013 |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/editorial-views-on/Edits/A-study-in-apathy/Article1-1120846.aspx |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130916160344/http://www.hindustantimes.com/editorial-views-on/Edits/A-study-in-apathy/Article1-1120846.aspx |archivedate=16 September 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
== Challenges == In the last 30 years, higher education in India has witnessed rapid and impressive growth. The increase in the number of institutions is, however, disproportionate to the quality of education that is being dispersed.<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=http://www.eaber.org/node/22139|title=Higher Education in India - The Need for Change {{!}} EABER|website=www.eaber.org|language=en|access-date=2018-03-14}}</ref> Unplanned over-expansion is often criticized as one of the biggest downfalls of Indian higher education.<ref name=":9">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/536293795|title=Indian higher education : envisioning the future|last=Pawan.|first=Agarwal,|date=2009|publisher=SAGE|isbn=9788178299419|location=New Delhi|oclc=536293795}}</ref> A large number of institutions suffer from subpar quality and a lack of funding. As a result, entry into the top institutions is highly competitive and translates into a contest for higher entrance test scores and better private coaching institutes.<ref name=":5" />
Higher education in India faces problems ranging from income and gender disparities in enrolment, to poor quality of faculty and teaching and even to a general lack of motivation and interest amongst students.<ref name=":5" /> Industries cite skill shortage as one of the major factors contributing to the mounting number of unemployed graduates.<ref name=":9" /> Some of the main challenges faced by the Indian higher education system include:
*'''Financing''' – The inability of the state to fund the expanding higher education system has resulted in the rapid growth of private higher education.<ref name=":5" /> In addition, diminished governmental financial support adversely affects small and rural educational institutions.<ref name=":22"/> A growing number of public institutions are forced to resort to self-financing courses and high tuition costs.<ref name=":5" /> The private sector's primary modes of financing include donations, capitation fees and exorbitant fee rates. This in turn limits general accessibility to higher education, by catering to only an elite few.<ref name=":22" /> *'''Enrolment''' – As of  2007, only around 11% of the 18 – 23 year old population of India, is enrolled in higher education. On the whole, India has an enrolment rate of 9% which is similar to that of other lower middle income countries. The population that is enrolled in higher education consists largely of urban metropolitan dwellers. Rural enrolment in higher education is very low.<ref name=":5" /> Moreover, a majority of the recorded enrolment is at the undergraduate level.<ref name=":9" /> Over the last 4 years, Indian higher education has maintained a steady female enrolment rate of around 45%.<ref>Government of India. Ministry of Human Resource Development.(2016) ''[http://aishe.nic.in/aishe/viewDocument.action;jsessionid=8D110DE571B80AE0C267A24451FFCA0C?documentId=204 All India Survey on Higher Education: Higher Education Statistics at a Glance]''</ref> Although the gender gap in enrolment has decreased significantly post-independence, there still exists a disparity amongst different departments. Technology, medicine and commerce are some of the areas of study that are heavily male-dominated while humanities departments show the opposite trend.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/1002303793|title=Politics, policy and higher education in India|last=Roy,|first=Chowdhury, Sunandan|isbn=9789811050565|location=Singapore|oclc=1002303793}}</ref> *'''Accreditation''' - Driven by market opportunities and entrepreneurial zeal, many institutions are taking advantage of the lax regulatory environment to offer 'degrees' not approved by Indian authorities, and many institutions are functioning as pseudo non-profit organisations, developing sophisticated financial methods to siphon off the 'profits'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.universityworldnews.com/article.php?story=20110722202005936|title=A crisis of confidence in higher education?|date=2011-07-24|publisher=universityworldnews.com|accessdate=2011-08-23}}</ref><ref>''Encyclopædia Britannica''</ref> Regulatory authorities like [[University Grants Commission (India)|UGC]] and [[All India Council for Technical Education|AICTE]] have been trying to extirpate private universities that run courses with no affiliation or recognition. Students from rural and semi-urban background often fall prey to these institutes and colleges.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20120915024214/http://thinkahead.net.in/tips-for-verifying-fake-and-cheat-universities-in-india/111038.html/ ''Fake and Cheat Universities in India'', Think Ahead.]</ref> *'''Politics''' - Higher education is a high stakes issue in India. It is subject to heavy government involvement. Despite the system's lack of state funding, 15.5% of government expenditure goes toward higher education.<ref name=":122">{{Cite journal|last=Altbach|first=Philip G.|date=1993-07-01|title=The dilemma of change in Indian higher education|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF01575104|journal=Higher Education|language=en|volume=26|issue=1|pages=3–20|doi=10.1007/BF01575104|issn=0018-1560}}</ref> Also, many prominent political figures either own or sit on the managerial board of the Universities.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ahmad Sheikh|first=Younis|date=2017|title=Higher Education in India: Challenges and Opportunities|url=https://files.eric.ed.gov/fulltext/EJ1131773.pdf|journal=Journal of Education and Practice|volume=8|pages=|via=}}</ref> This leads to the exertion of intense political pressures on the administration of these institutions.<ref name=":122" /> [[Caste system in India|Caste]] based reservations make Indian higher education an even more contested topic. While some make the case that caste-based quotas are necessary to tackle prevailing socio-economic disparities,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ghosh|first=Jayati|date=2006|title=Case for Caste-Based Quotas in Higher Education|jstor=4418343|journal=Economic and Political Weekly|volume=41|issue=24|pages=2428–2432}}</ref> others see it as exclusionary to upper-caste individuals.<ref>{{Cite journal|title=Politics, Policy and Higher Education in India {{!}} SpringerLink|url=https://link.springer.com/content/pdf/10.1007/978-981-10-5056-5.pdf|language=en-gb|doi=10.1007/978-981-10-5056-5.pdf}}</ref> As a result, student activism and political organization of academic staff are widespread and rampant.
The complex socio-political nature of the education sector in India makes it difficult to implement social reform. As a result, the overall quality of education suffers.<ref name=":122"/>
== Student advisory == While fee regulatory agencies fix a fee that cover expenses incurred by an institution along with a basic surplus,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.frctech.ac.in/2011_NewFee/mba_frc.pdf|accessdate=17 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afrcmp.org/index.php/2015-11-25-08-40-18|accessdate=17 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://ojee.nic.in/publicinfo/Handler/FileHandler.ashx?i=File&ii=98&iii=Y|accessdate=17 September 2016}}</ref> many institutions have been charging a fee<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.moneycontrol.com/news/others/thinkingan-mba-knowreal-costs_882184.html|accessdate=17 September 2016}}</ref> that makes the venture profiteering. All India Council for Technical Education (AICTE), the regulatory body for technical education in India, has called "upon the students, parents and the general public not to pay any [[capitation fee]] or any other fee other than that mentioned in the Prospectus of the Institutions for consideration of admission."<ref>http://www.aicte-india.org/downloads/notice_prohibition_capitation_fee.pdf</ref> AICTE also mentions that the fee charged to students, including for programs such as PGDM, has to be approved by the fee regulatory committee of the state, and the institute should mention the fee on its website.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aicte-india.org/downloads/ApprovalProcessHandbook2016-17.pdf|accessdate=17 September 2016}}</ref> As per AICTE norms, the business schools are not meant to charge a fee higher than what is mentioned in the prospectus. Educational regulatory agencies, at the national level<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ugc.ac.in/pdfnews/1842250_deemedregulation2014.PDF|accessdate=17 September 2016}}</ref> and the regional level,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://asckerala.org/sites/default/files/MBA%20DIRECTIVES%20ISSUED%20TO%20ALL%20SELF-FINANICNG%20MANAGEMENT%20INSTITUTUES%20ON%2011.05.2015.pdf|accessdate=17 September 2016}}</ref> have mandated that an institution should include the fee in the prospectus.
==See also== * [[Academic ranks in India]] * [[Capitation fee]] * [[Education in India]] * [[List of universities in India]]
